QAMichaelPeng

double pointer

Nov 28, 2014

Double pointer is a great tool to simplify certain programming tasks.

Letâ€™s look into a simple example: merge two sorted linked list by spicing together the nodes of the orignal lists without creating new nodes.

Below is the define of linked node:

1 struct ListNode {
2     int val;
3     ListNode *next;
4     ListNode(int x) : val(x), next(NULL) {}
5 };

The simplest way is use a pointer h to record the head of merged list, and use another pointer p to record the tail of merged results;

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode* h = NULL, *p = NULL;
 3     while (l1 && l2) {
 4         if (l1->val <= l2->val) {
 5             if (!h) {
 6                 h = p = l1;
 7             }
 8             else {
 9                 p->next = l1;
10                 p = l1;
11             }
12             l1 = l1->next;
13         }
14         else {
15             if (!h) {
16                 h = p = l2;
17             }
18             else {
19                 p->next = l2;
20                 p = l2;
21             }
22             l2 = l2->next;
23         }
24     }
25     if (!h) h = l1 ? l1 : l2;
26     else p->next = l1 ? l1 : l2;
27     return h;
28 }

hmm, too many nested if else in the 28 line solution. How to elimate the detect of NULL of head? One trick is to use a dummy node.

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode dummy(-1), *p = &dummy;
 3     for (; l1 != nullptr && l2 != nullptr; p = p->next) {
 4         if (l1->val > l2->val) {
 5             p->next = l2;
 6             l2 = l2->next;
 7         }
 8         else { 
 9             p->next = l1;
10             l1 = l1->next;
11         }
12     }
13     p->next = l1 != nullptr ? l1 : l2;
14     return dummy.next;
15 }

Here we got a 15 line solution, 13 lines are elimated. Here a dummy node elemated the check of NULL for head and prev pointer. But how can we elimate the construct of a new dummy load if the cost is heavy? Double pointer may help.

 1 ListNode *mergeTwoLists(ListNode *l1, ListNode *l2) {
 2     ListNode* h = NULL, **p = &h;
 3     for (;l1&&l2;p=&((*p)->next)) {
 4         if (l1->val <= l2->val) {
 5             *p = l1;
 6             l1 = l1->next;
 7         }
 8         else {
 9             *p = l2;
10             l2 = l2->next;
11         }
12     }
13     *p = l1 ? l1 : l2;
14     return h;
15 }

Hereâ€™re some quizzes you can try with double pointer.

  • Remove Nth Node From End of List
  • Insertion Sort List
  • Reverse Linked List II
  • Partition List
  • Merge Two Sorted Lists
